In the semi-hydrogenation of acetylene, nickel-based catalysts offer a promising alternative to precious metal palladium catalysts. Despite the positive hydrogenation activity of nickel-based catalysts, there is still room for improvement in terms of their selectivity and stability. In this study, a simple incipient wetness impregnation method was employed to prepare Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst and its performance in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene was investigated. It was found that under the conditions of 170 °C and a space velocity of 600 h−1, the 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst achieved a 95.3 % acetylene conversion with an 85.6 % ethylene selectivity. Furthermore, the catalyst exhibited outstanding stability over a 100 hour test. TEM, XPS and C2H4-TPD experiments showed that the Ni species were encapsulated in the ionic liquids (ILs), and the interaction between the metal ions, nickel, and the ILs ensured a high dispersion and stability of the actives on the carriers, and the electronic effect between the ionic nickel and the ionic liquids increased the electron cloud density of the Ni, which improved the catalyst selectivity, which is the main reason for its excellent catalytic performance. Graphical Abstract Efficient selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene catalyzed by ionic liquid (ILs)-encapsulated nickel ions Abbreviations Al2O3 Aluminum oxide ILs ionic liquid GHSV gas hourly space velocities [BMIM]PF6 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate SILC supported ionic liquid catalysis Keywords Acetylene semi-hydrogenation Nickel-based catalyst Ionic liquid Interaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene is a crucial raw material for various chemical products, including important monomers like polyethylene, polypropylene, and polyvinyl chloride [1–4]. In the olefin industry, ethylene is primarily obtained through the thermal cracking of hydrocarbons. However, the ethylene feedstock obtained through cracking contains a small amount of acetylene impurities (0.1–1 %). The presence of trace amounts of acetylene not only leads to irreversible deactivation of downstream ethylene polymerization catalysts but also poses an explosion risk during acetylene polymerization [5–8]. Therefore, the selective removal of trace acetylene is highly important in the olefin industry. The selective hydrogenation method, due to its simple process, economic advantages, and environmental friendliness, has been widely applied in industry [9,10]. Palladium-based catalysts have been extensively studied in the past few decades, with silver-modified palladium catalysts finding successful industrial applications [11,12]. However, the high cost of palladium and the key drawback of excessive hydrogenation of ethylene to ethane remain critical issues for palladium catalysts. The scarcity of palladium has led to increased interest in alternative selective hydrogenation catalysts [13,14]. Nickel-based catalysts emerge as a promising alternative to palladium catalysts. Nickel is more cost-effective than palladium, making nickel-based catalysts a sustainable and economically viable choice. Although nickel exhibits good hydrogenation activity, it tends to promote the oligomerization of hydrocarbon reactants, significantly reducing the selectivity for ethylene [15,16]. Some researchers have improved ethylene selectivity by forming alloys of active and inert metals [17,18]. Others have achieved favorable ethylene production by dispersing active metal sites, adjusting the catalyst's geometric structure and electronic properties [19,20]. While alloying can enhance ethylene selectivity, bimetallic catalysts still generate ethane and oligomers. The use of gold or other precious metals as alloying elements further increases catalyst costs [21]. Therefore, developing catalysts that are low-cost, highly active, selective, and stable is essential for the application of ethylene selective hydrogenation. Ionic liquids (ILs) have garnered widespread attention in various fields due to their unique advantages, such as extremely low vapor pressure, high thermal stability, excellent solvating properties, and tunability in separation and catalysis processes [22–24]. On the one hand, studies have shown that imidazole-type ILs with cationic imidazolium moieties exhibit good separation selectivity for ethylene and acetylene [25]. On the other hand, ILs play a role in modifying catalysts. ILs can be combined with catalysts through simple physical adsorption or covalent bonding, providing additional active sites or altering the surface properties of the catalyst, resulting in significant changes in catalyst activity and selectivity [23,24,26]. Supported ionic liquid catalysis (SILC) combines the advantages of ILs and solid carriers by immobilizing or "loading" ILs onto the surface of solid carriers or catalysts to enhance the performance of catalytic reactions [27]. The combination of cations and anions of ILs can be adjusted according to the requirements of specific reactions [28], and the actual concentration can be tailored based on the distinct characteristics of the support material [29]. In addition, Liang et al. [30] prepared a series of magnesium pincer complexes, Xu et al. [31] used ionic liquids as ligands to form Pd carbene substances with Pd in acetylene semi-hydrogenation with excellent yields and selectivity. All these aspects highlight the potential value of ILs as solvents and modifiers in the catalytic hydrogenation of acetylene. Inspired by supported ionic liquid catalysis (SILC) and transition metal complex-catalyzed selective hydrogenation, this study employed a simple e incipient wetness impregnation method to prepare Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst for investigating the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. The catalyst, prepared under conditions of 170 °C temperature, a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 600 h−1, H2∶C2H2=10∶1, and C2H4∶C2H2=100∶1, achieved a remarkable 95.3 % acetylene conversion and an 85.6 % ethylene selectivity. We characterized the catalyst's chemical composition, physical properties, and structure, and explored the potential mechanism through which IL enhances catalytic selectivity. Preliminary results suggest promising industrial applications for the 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst. 2 Experimental section and evaluation 2.1 Materials 40–60 mesh γ-Al2O3 was obtained from the Tianjin Research Institute of Chemical Industry. Ni(OAC)2·4 H2O (nickel acetate tetrahydrate) was purchased from Aladdin Chemical Co., Ltd. Methanol (CH3OH) was obtained from Aladdin Chemical Co., Ltd. The ionic liquid, [BMIM][PF6] (1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate), was provided by the Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics. All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalyst preparation process is illustrated in Fig.S1. Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalysts and Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using an equal-volume impregnation method. Initially, 1.765 g of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate ([BMIM]PF6) was individually weighed in a 20 mL flask. Subsequently, 0.152 g, 0.301 g, 0.911 g, and 1.526 g of nickel acetate tetrahydrate were added in three portions to the pre-weighed [BMIM]PF6. The mixture was stirred at 140 °C in an oil bath for 4 hours, with periodic checks every 20 minutes to ensure the uniform clarity of the solution. This step ensured complete dissolution of nickel acetate tetrahydrate in [BMIM]PF6, resulting in [BMIM]PF6-Ni(OAC)2 impregnation solution, hereafter referred to as Ni(OAC)2-IL. Finally, the four prepared ionic liquids were dissolved in a specified amount of methanol solvent, transferred to a 10 mL volumetric flask, and topped up to the corresponding mark with methanol. By pipetting, various volumes of different concentrations [BMIM]PF6-Ni(OAC)2 impregnation solutions were taken and added to petri dishes. Subsequently, a certain mass of γ-Al2O3 support (40–60 mesh) was uniformly and slowly poured into the impregnation solution. The petri dish was gently tapped to ensure the even spreading of the Al2O3 support in the impregnation solution. The mixture was left to stand at room temperature for 12 hours to allow sufficient impregnation of the nickel solution onto the Al2O3 support. The samples were then placed in a vacuum drying oven at 110 °C, evacuated, and dried for 12 hours, followed by cooling to room temperature. The ionic liquid content in all catalysts was approximately 5 wt %. Catalysts with different nickel contents denoted as xNi(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 (where x = 0.5 %, 1 %, 3 %, 5 %), were prepared using a similar procedure. Corresponding Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalysts were also prepared following a similar protocol, denoted as xNi(OAC)2//Al2O3. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The performance of the catalysts used in the reaction was assessed using a batch reaction continuous hydrogenation unit produced by Pengxiang Technology Co., Ltd. in Tianjin. The outer diameter of the quartz reaction tube was 10 mm, and the inner diameter was 6 mm, as illustrated in Fig. 1. A suitable amount of quartz wool was placed at the center of the quartz tube, and the theoretical catalyst volume under different gas hourly space velocities (GHSV) was calculated using the formula for GHSV. 1.5 mL of catalyst samples were then measured using a graduated cylinder and packed into the constant temperature zone of the reaction tube (bed height of 30–40 cm). The reaction tube was secured within a heating jacket. Subsequently, a leak check was performed on the entire reaction system. After introducing nitrogen into the reaction system, a soap bubble test was conducted at the interface to ensure gas tightness, observing the continuous release of bubbles from the tail gas bottle outlet to confirm the good airtightness of the reaction system. The temperature ramping program was initiated with a heating rate of 10 °C/min during the nitrogen purging process. Once the set activation temperature was reached, the catalyst was activated for 2 hours before cooling to room temperature. The temperature controller was set to ramp up to the reaction temperature at a rate of 10 °C/min. Upon reaching a stable temperature, nitrogen flow was halted, and the reaction gas was introduced. Reaction conditions: Temperature of 170 °C, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) = 600 h⁻¹, H2:C2H2 = 10:1, C2H4:C2H2 = 100:1. We employed the Fuli GC9790 gas chromatograph to perform online quantitative analysis of the product mixture gas after the selective hydrogenation of acetylene, followed by calculating the acetylene conversion rate and ethylene selectivity of the catalyst during the reaction. The specific chromatographic analysis conditions are shown in Table S2. Quantitative analysis of the reaction gases was conducted using the peak area normalization method, where the content of each component in the chromatographic analysis is represented by the percentage of peak area. The correction factor for substances was obtained through online calibration. The formula for calculating the mass fraction of each component is as follows: X i = A i f i A 1 f 1 + A 2 f 2 + A 3 f 3 + ⋯ + A n f n × 100 % = m i m 1 + m 2 + m 3 + ⋯ + m n × 100 % Where: X i is the mass fraction of the total components accounted for by component i in the sample; A i is the peak area of component i in the sample in the chromatogram; m i is the amount of substance of component i in the sample; f i is the correction factor for gas i. The values of correction factors for different gases are shown in Table S3. The ethyne conversion rate, ethene selectivity, and ethene yield during the reaction were calculated using the following formulas: Ethyne Conversion Rate = (Ethyne (Inlet) - Ethyne (Outlet)) / (Ethyne (Inlet)) × 100 % Ethene Selectivity = (Ethene (Outlet) - Ethene (Inlet)) / (Ethyne (Inlet) - Ethyne (Outlet)) × 100 % Ethene Yield = Ethyne Conversion Rate × Ethene Selectivity 2.4 Catalyst characterization The physical structure parameters of the catalysts were tested using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 automatic specific surface area and pore size analyzer (BET). The catalysts were degassed under vacuum conditions at T = 200 °C for 5 hours. Subsequently, nitrogen physical adsorption was conducted at liquid nitrogen temperature, and desorption was performed to measure the nitrogen adsorption capacity under conditions ranging from 10−7 to 0.1 MPa. The changes in catalyst specific surface area, pore diameter, and pore volume before and after the reaction were obtained through N2 adsorption-desorption experiments. PANalytical X′Pert Pro diffractometer from Panaco, Netherlands, was employed to analyze the prepared samples. Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1541 nm) was used as the X-ray source. The instrument was tested at 45 kV tube voltage, 40 mA tube current, and a scanning rate of 5°·min−1. The scanning range was set from 10 to 80°. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to observe the submicroscopic or ultra-microscopic structures of the samples, providing information on sample morphology and crystal structure. The model of the transmission electron microscope used was Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin, operating at 300 kV with an equipped EDS analyzer for observing the types and distribution of elements. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) was employed to study catalyst carbon deposition and thermal stability during the reaction. The STA 449 C Jupiter thermal analyzer produced by NETZSCH, Germany, was used in experiments conducted in air or inert gas atmospheres at a flow rate of 30 mL/min, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The curve of catalyst mass change with temperature was obtained by heating the 10 mg sample from 50 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Temperature Programmed Reduction-Mass Spectrometry (TPR-MS) primarily tested the reduction temperature of different species and could be used to analyze the oxidation states of species during the reaction. The instruments used in the experiment were the Bel Cata II mainframe and the Bel Mass mass spectrometer. The program involved ramping from room temperature to 110 °C in a He gas flow (50 mL/min) for 1 hour, followed by cooling to 40 °C, and finally introducing a 5 % H2 /He mixed gas (50 mL/min) with a ramping rate of 10 °C/min to 800 °C for reduction. The Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of the samples were recorded using a Shimadzu IRAffinity-1 FTIR spectrometer (in the form of KBr pellets) in the range of 4000–500 cm–1. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku X-ray machine operating at 40 kV and 150 mA. Ethene Temperature-Programmed Desorption (C2H4-TPD) was conducted using the Bel Cata II mainframe, and C2H2-TPD-MS employed the AutoChem1 II 2920 model. For the temperature-programmed desorption, 100 mg of the sample was first placed in a reaction tube. The sample was dried and pretreated by heating from room temperature to 110 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under He gas flow (50 mL/min) for 1 hour. The sample was then reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere at 200 °C for 1 hour, followed by He gas purging (50 mL/min) for 1 hour to remove weakly adsorbed species on the surface. Finally, the temperature was ramped up to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under He gas flow. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze information about the molecular structure and atomic valence states of the catalysts. The X-ray photoelectron spectrometer used in the experiment was the Kratos AXOS Ultra DLD, produced by Shimadzu Corporation (Japan), with a monochromatic Al target Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). In the analysis, the binding energies of all elements' peaks were corrected using the C1s peak (B.E. = 284.6 eV). 3 Results and discussion The catalysts, including 3 % Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3, 0.5 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3, 1 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3, 3 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3, and 5 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3, were evaluated in the acetylene selective hydrogenation reaction apparatus shown in Fig. 2. The results are depicted in Figs. 3a and 3b under the following reaction conditions: temperature at 170 °C, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) at 600 h−1, reaction gas mixture (H2:C2H2 = 10:1, C2H4:C2H2 = 100:1), IL = [BMIM][PF6]. It can be observed that the 5 % IL /Al2O3 catalyst is almost inactive and the conversion of acetylene is around 5 %. The initial activity of 3 % Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst without IL is 100 %, with a selectivity of approximately −50 %. After the introduction of IL, the selectivity is significantly improved, with a slight decrease in conversion. Keeping the IL content constant, as the nickel loading increases, the acetylene conversion increases gradually from 33.3 % to 95.6 %, while the ethylene selectivity only decreases from 92.0 % to 77.8 %. This indicates that the introduction of IL effectively enhances the ethylene selectivity. When the nickel loading is increased to 5 %, not only does the selectivity decrease, but there is also a slight decrease in activity, which may be related to excessive nickel loading leading to insufficient dispersion of active centers. In summary, the 3 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3 ratio appears to be suitable, yielding favorable evaluation results. Under the conditions of 95.3 % acetylene conversion, the ethylene selectivity is 85.6 %. Compared to Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 with a selectivity of approximately −50 %, the selectivity of 3 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3 increases by 130 %. The difference in selectivity is attributed to the shielding effect of the ionic liquid (IL) and the interaction between the active center Ni and the ILs, which may affect the electron acceptance of nickel. The interaction may be the creation of coordination between the active center Ni and ILs in the 3 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL /Al2O3 catalyst, increasing the electron cloud density of the Ni species and thus improving the ethylene selectivity. Stability is a crucial indicator in industrial applications. To further evaluate the industrial application potential of the catalysts, we conducted a long-term evaluation of 3 %Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 and 3 %Ni(OAC)2-5%IL/Al2O3. Fig. 3a shows that 3 %Ni/(OAC)2Al2O3 gradually loses activity over the 50-hour evaluation. In contrast, Fig. 3b indicates that 3 %Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 achieves an initial acetylene conversion rate of 92.7 %, slowly increasing during the reaction, reaching a maximum acetylene conversion rate of 96.8 %. The catalyst shows no deactivation phenomenon during the 100-hour evaluation, maintaining a stable acetylene conversion rate of around 95.3 % and an ethylene selectivity of around 85.6 %. Therefore, we believe that the high-performance non-precious metal 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst has the potential for industrial applications and holds significance for the development of commercial non-precious metal catalysts. In addition, we also compared the performance of our prepared catalysts with the performance of catalysts previously reported in the literature (Table S4) and found that there is an advantage in the performance of our prepared catalysts. The fresh Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3, Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3, IL/Al2O3, and deactivated Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalysts were subjected to BET characterization analysis. The characterization results are presented in Table 1 and Fig. 4a. All samples exhibited a typical "IV" isotherm with a narrow and uniform H1 hysteresis loop in the range of P/P0 from 0.5 to 1.0. Compared to γ-Al2O3, the temperature adsorption-desorption curve of the Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 and IL/Al2O3 catalyst underwent significant changes, with a noticeable loss in mesopore volume for ratios exceeding 0.5, which may be attributed to the introduction of IL. According to the results in Table 1, the specific surface area of γ-Al2O3 is approximately 283.65 m2/g, and after introducing IL, the specific surface area of the Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 and IL/Al2O3 catalyst significantly decreased. With a constant IL loading, the specific surface area and pore volume decreased as the nickel loading increased, confirming the successful loading of Ni(OAC)2-IL on the Al2O3 support. In comparison to the fresh Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst (specific surface area of 277.33 m2/g), the deactivated Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a significantly reduced specific surface area of 40.87 m2/g, accompanied by a decrease in pore volume and a noticeable increase in pore size. Therefore, the physical structure of the deactivated Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst underwent significant changes, which may be the cause of its deactivation. The fresh and post-reaction Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalysts were subjected to XRD characterization analysis, and the results are shown in Fig. 4b. All samples exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.63°, 39.49°, 45.78°, and 66.76°, corresponding to the (311), (222), (400), and (440) crystal planes of γ-Al2O3 respectively [32]. Additionally, no distinct diffraction peaks at 37.1°, 43.2°, 52.2°, and 75.2°, characteristic of nickel or nickel oxide crystals [33,34], were detected in both fresh and used catalysts. This suggests that nickel species are uniformly dispersed on the support or exist in an amorphous form. Furthermore, a slight reduction in crystallinity was observed in the Al2O3 support of the Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst after encapsulation with IL and after the reaction. This might be attributed to changes in the external surface morphology of the Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst after IL encapsulation, while the deactivated Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst showed the deposition of coke or certain polymers on the external surface of the Al2O3 support. Subsequent TEM and EDS semi-quantitative analysis revealed the presence of other elements on the surface, indicating the presence of a layer of ionic liquid, which did not affect the original crystal structure of the catalyst. To gain insights into the morphology and activity distribution behavior of the catalysts, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterization was conducted on fresh and post-use 3 %Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 and 3 %Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalysts. TEM images in Fig. 4 reveal clear Ni0 or NiO particles in the 3 %Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst, with an average size of approximately 1.44 nm. After 10 hours of evaluation, particle size increased to 4.83 nm, possibly due to partial decomposition of nickel acetate into NiO particles and subsequent growth of NiO and Ni particles during the reaction. No NiO or Ni0 particles were observed in both fresh and used 3 %Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalysts, indicating the successful encapsulation and protection of Ni(OAC)2 by the ionic liquid. Moreover, there were no significant morphological changes observed during the reaction process for the 3 %Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst, suggesting its resistance to aggregation or sintering. Due to the similar contrast between Ni and Al2O3, distinguishing the active component Ni from the Al2O3 support with certain thickness was not feasible. Therefore, mapping was employed to characterize the presence of Ni, P, N, Al, and other elements in the precursor. Fig. 5c and S5 depict the mapping and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) images of fresh and used 3 %Ni(OAC)-IL/Al2O3 catalysts. The mapping images confirm the presence of Ni, P, N, Al, and other elements uniformly distributed on the catalyst surface without forming particle clusters. These characterization data collectively indicate the high dispersion of nickel on the prepared catalyst, consistent with the aforementioned XRD results. To verify whether the catalyst surface carbon leads to the deactivation of the 3 %Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst [35] and to investigate the reasons for the enhanced stability upon introducing the ionic liquid, fresh Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 and deactivated Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 were subjected to thermogravimetric (TG) analysis under ambient air conditions. The TG and DTG curves are presented in Fig. 6. For both fresh and deactivated 3 %Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalysts, a noticeable weight loss before 110 °C can be attributed to the evaporation of residual water in the catalyst. In the temperature range of 150–300 °C, the catalyst experiences weight loss, believed to be due to the combustion of amorphous carbon. Calculations based on the catalyst's weight loss indicate that the carbon accumulation in the deactivated catalyst is approximately 23.63 % of the total catalyst weight, suggesting significant coking during the reaction [36]. This aligns with the results from BET characterization analysis. The introduction of the ionic liquid results in the formation of an ionic liquid film uniformly coating the outer layer of Ni. This diminishes the strong adsorption of oligomers at the active centers. In addition, the ionic liquid has a stabilizing effect on Ni, which constrains the growth or aggregation of metal nanoparticles within the confines of the ionic liquid. NH3-TPD results for both fresh 3 %Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst and 3 %Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. S6) indicate a reduction in the strong acid amount and acidity upon introducing the ionic liquid. This reduction is a key factor contributing to the significant enhancement in catalytic performance. For the fresh and used 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst(Fig. S7), the thermal gravimetric (TG) analysis under air atmosphere reveals that the weight loss peak at 110 °C is attributed to the evaporation of residual moisture in the catalyst. The small weight loss peak observed in the range of 210 °C to 250 °C for fresh 3 %Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalysts is speculated to be associated with the thermal decomposition of a small amount of ionic liquid [37]. The rapid weight loss beyond 370 °C is believed to be primarily due to the thermal decomposition of nickel acetate and the ionic liquid itself [38,39]. The weight loss peak of the used 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst is around 420 °C, we consider the thermal decomposition of nickel acetate and nickel acetate and the ionic liquid itself, and the difference between the two may be related to the ionic liquid-Ni interaction. It can be concluded that the catalyst exhibits good stability under the reaction temperature of 170 °C. Coating the active centers of the Ni(OAC)2 catalyst with an ionic liquid (IL) layer significantly enhances the catalyst's selectivity. The improved selectivity may be attributed to the differences in the solubility of reaction gases in the ionic liquid, hydrogen and ethylene exhibit lower solubility[40,41], with [BMIM][PF6] ionic liquid favoring acetylene dissolution [42]. These solubility variations could play a crucial role in the actual reaction environment [43,44]. Furthermore, the geometric and electronic properties of nickel metal nanoparticles loaded in the IL can be influenced by the proper selection of IL cations and anions [45]. We hypothesize that the introduction of IL results in a strong interaction between nickel and IL, causing a change in the electronic properties of the active centers. To investigate the interaction between Ni and the ionic liquid, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) tests were conducted on the IL/Al2O3, 3 %Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 and the 3 %Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8a, IL/Al2O3 exhibited a broad peak around 350 °C, which may be attributed to the thermal decomposition of IL. The Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits a reduction peak at 503 °C, likely corresponding to the reduction of NiO formed after high-temperature decomposition. In contrast, the Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst shows reduction peaks at 328 °C and 497 °C, attributed to the decomposition of IL and the two-step reduction of Ni2+ [46–48]. This suggests that the active component nickel in both catalysts participates in the reaction with a valence state of Ni2+ before 200 °C. Compared to the TPR curve of Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3, the reduction peaks of Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 shift to lower temperatures, indicating that the introduction of the ionic liquid facilitates the reduction of Ni2+. This shift may be due to the formation of a coordination complex between Ni2+ and the IL, resulting in stronger interactions [49]. Additionally, Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits broader peaks, suggesting a higher abundance of Ni2+ active species and highlighting the favorable impact of the ionic liquid on the dispersion of nickel species. Infrared spectroscopy can probe the interaction between ILs and nickel species [50]. Infrared spectra were obtained for fresh and used 3 %Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3, 3 %Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3, and IL/Al2O3 catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 8b. Characteristic peaks around 680 cm−1, 1290–1520 cm−1, 2360 cm−1, 1650 cm−1, and 3100–3500 cm−1 are attributed to Al-O stretching vibrations [51], C-O stretching vibrations [52], instrument CO2 gas [53], and adsorbed water or hydrogen-bonded -OH bending vibrations in the catalyst [54]. Pure [BMIM][PF6]/Al2O3 exhibits broad peaks around 3171 cm−1 and 3125 cm−1, believed to be characteristic peaks of C4,5-H and C2-H in the imidazole ring [55]. In the 3 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3 catalyst, these characteristic peaks disappear upon IL introduction, indicating the anchoring of [BMIM]+ cations on the Al2O3 support [56]. This confirms the successful loading of IL onto the support material and suggests a strong interaction between [BMIM]+ and Ni. Furthermore, two main peaks at 820–860 cm−1 and 550–565 cm−1 correspond to P-F stretching and bending vibrations [57]. Both features are detectable in the unreacted 3 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3 catalyst. Interestingly, these two characteristic peaks significantly decrease in the reacted 3 % Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3 catalyst. It can be inferred that the interaction is likely achieved through coordination between [BMIM]+ cations or [PF6]- anions and Ni2+, and these interactions contribute to the high dispersion of nickel species. These findings are consistent with the TPR analysis. To further elucidate the oxidation state of Ni species and their interaction with IL, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the chemical states and electronic environments of nickel species, nitrogen species and phosphorus species in 3 % Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3, IL/Al2O3 and 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8a, Ni 2p XPS spectra for all Ni catalysts exhibit two spin-split peaks attributed to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2. Gaussian deconvolution was employed to fit these peaks. The binding energy of Ni 2p3/2 for fresh and reacted 3 % Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst is 856.3 eV, indicative of Ni2+; no characteristic peaks of Ni0 species were observed, suggesting the presence of Ni species in a high oxidation state [58,59]. However, with the introduction of IL, a significant shift in the peak position of nickel active species is observed. In 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3, the binding energy of Ni species is 855.7 eV, lower than that in 3 % Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3, indicating that the electron cloud density of the Ni species was elevated, and the adsorption strength of ethylene in the active Ni sites was weakened, with rapid desorption of ethylene and increased ethylene selectivity [24,31,60]. The N 1 s and P 2p XPS spectra of fresh IL/Al2O3 and 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 8(b-e). There is no significant change in the binding energy of P 2p XPS for both catalysts, indicating no coordination interaction between [PF6]- anions and Ni2+. However, in the N 1s spectrum of the IL/Al2O3 catalyst, a single peak appears at a binding energy of 402.0 eV, corresponding to the equivalent nitrogen atom in [BMIM]+ in the ionic liquid [61]. In comparison with the IL/Al2O3 catalyst, the binding energy of N in the N 1 s spectrum of the 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst shifts to higher binding energy, and another characteristic peak appears at a binding energy of around 400.4 eV. The new N 1 s peak is possibly attributed to N-heterocyclic carbenes generated from imidazole-based ionic liquids [31,62]. We speculate that the N in IL coordinates with nickel to form a carbene, with electron transfer from nitrogen to nickel. The ethylene adsorption capacity of the catalysts was studied using C2H4-TPD. Results in Fig. 9 reveal two desorption peak patterns corresponding to physical and chemical adsorption for both catalysts. The desorption peak at around 97.1 °C in Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 and Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 corresponds to the physical desorption of ethylene. Notably, the peak at 370.5 °C in 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 represents the desorption of ethylene in a π-bonding mode on the active Ni component, while the peak at 417.4 °C corresponds to the desorption of ethylene in a δ-bonding mode on Ni. Meanwhile, for 3 % Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3, the desorption temperatures for π-bonding and δ-bonding modes are 409.7 °C and 458.1 °C, respectively. The desorption temperature for ethylene is approximately 46.9 °C lower in Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 compared to Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3, indicating weaker adsorption, easier desorption, and explaining the higher ethylene selectivity of Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3. The addition of IL weakens the adsorption capacity of Ni for ethylene, enhancing catalyst performance. In summary, we employed a straightforward incipient wetness impregnation method to fabricate an environmentally friendly and efficient Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst for acetylene semi-hydrogenation. In comparison to the Ni(OAC)2/Al2O3 catalyst, the Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited significant improvements in selectivity and stability. Specifically, the 3 %Ni(OAC)2-5 %IL/Al2O3 catalyst under reaction conditions of 170 °C and GHSV=600 h−1 achieved a remarkable acetylene conversion rate of 95.3 % and an ethylene selectivity of 85.6 % over a 100 hour reaction period. XRD, TEM and XPS results confirm that the electronic effect between Ni2+ and ionic liquid is the main reason for the high reaction selectivity. The combination and interaction between the metal ion active centers and the stable ionic liquid layer, ILs have both protective and stabilizing effects on Ni, the coordination of imidazole cations in ILs with ionic nickel changed the electronic structure of the catalyst. Furthermore, the encapsulation of Ni by the ionic liquid reduced the strong adsorption of ethylene by the active centers, decreasing the acidity of the catalyst. This reduction in acidity contributed to the enhanced stability of the catalyst. These factors not only significantly improved catalytic performance but also mitigated catalyst deactivation during the reaction. Therefore, we contend that the 3 %Ni(OAC)2-5 % IL/Al2O3 catalyst, as a high-performance non-precious metal catalyst, not only holds promise for potential industrial applications but also provides valuable insights for the development of commercial non-precious metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In the semi-hydrogenation of acetylene, nickel-based catalysts offer a promising alternative to precious metal palladium catalysts. Despite the positive hydrogenation activity of nickel-based catalysts, there is still room for improvement in terms of their selectivity and stability. In this study, a simple incipient wetness impregnation method was employed to prepare Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst and its performance in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene was investigated. It was found that under the conditions of 170 °C and a space velocity of 600 h−1, the 3 % Ni(OAC)2-IL/Al2O3 catalyst achieved a 95.3 % acetylene conversion with an 85.6 % ethylene selectivity. Furthermore, the catalyst exhibited outstanding stability over a 100 hour test. TEM, XPS and C2H4-TPD experiments showed that the Ni species were encapsulated in the ionic liquids (ILs), and the interaction between the metal ions, nickel, and the ILs ensured a high dispersion and stability of the actives on the carriers, and the electronic effect between the ionic nickel and the ionic liquids increased the electron cloud density of the Ni, which improved the catalyst selectivity, which is the main reason for its excellent catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient catalysis of acetylene semi-hydrogenation through synergistic action of supported ionic liquid-nickel catalyst
